Reviews.Title: Good pocket camera
Reviews.Author: Doug Hibbard
Reviews.Content: Fujifilm's FinePix Z90 is, obviously, a digital camera. I won't replay the statistics for you, since they are listed in the product description. Here are the highpoints of my experience with this camera:1. The FinePix uses a rechargeable battery which is included. The drawback here is that you must charge the battery before the first use of the camera. If it used normal batteries, you could pop them in and move on. However, rechargeable keeps the waste down, and ordering your camera to arrive a day or two before you need it will give you plenty of time. Initial charge actually took a little under 2 hours. The charger is included. You can purchase an additional battery if you like.2. Battery life: I have taken this camera along on a couple of short family day-trips and taken somewhere between 20-30 pictures each trip. Between that and taking pictures just to take pictures, I've taken well over a hundred pictures. So far, the battery has held up just fine and not needed recharged. This includes after sitting around and not being used at all for a couple of days. Let's face it: with a camera, you want it to work when you pick it up. This one does pretty well.3. Picture quality: I am not much of a photographer, but I can tell lousy, blurry pictures when I see them. So far, I'm not seeing any with my FinePix. The image stabilization seems to work well, the flash fills nicely, and the "Auto" setting has kept the quality consistent indoors and out.4. Controlling the camera with a touchscreen: this has been difficult to adjust to doing, but I'm getting used to it. I don't know of a touchscreen control that I've ever been truly happy with, however this one is good enough.5. Included software: I used the included software a little bit, but not a lot. I wasn't impressed and found the free software I've been using to be just fine. This is partly because I prefer to eject the card from the camera and use the card reader on the computer. I didn't bother learning the new software and just continue to use what I've been using.The other reason I chose to not bother with the included software is what I would deem my one major complaint with this camera: the USB docking cord. It's not a mini-USB or a micro-USB. It's shaped just a little different. This means using the included software for import requires keeping one more cord on my desktop or handy. Too much trouble---I'm already too good at collecting clutter. I'm not sure there was a technical reason not to make the cord match existing cords, but it doesn't.6. Time to shoot: this is my favorite thing about this camera. I pick it up, snap the cover down, and take a picture. My wife has an Olympus that takes slightly better pictures, has a better zoom, and a better video feature. But if our son is up to something cute and silly, I can get two pictures taken before she can take one, and that can be all the difference.7. One fun feature: I thought this was fun, but you might find it stupid. The camera can be set to take two quick pictures with one push. One with flash, one without. So, in those situations where you don't know if you need the flash, you don't have to repose or re-snap. It's done.This is a definite step-up from my daughter's entry-level camera, but obviously you can't expect it to be as amazing as cameras that run into the hundreds and thousands. For me, a dad trying to capture memories here and there, it's a good fit.

Reviews.Title: A versatile and tough little take-along camera
Reviews.Author: Jeddy 3
Reviews.Content: This is my second Fuji camera. (My first was a sturdy sandproof/waterproof model, the XP, which has served me very well at the beach and on boats.)I'm mostly a Canon gal myself, and I have to say the Fuji interface takes a little getting used to. After poking around for 15 minutes, pressing buttons and exploring menus, I think you'll find this camera pretty intuitive. In many ways, the menus are easier to navigate than Canon's. That's a good thing, because the enclosed instructions are sparse (though a full set is included in .pdf form on the enclosed CD).This camera won my favor before I even used it because of the delightful "form factor" -- it's pretty, it's colorful, it's compact, it's pleasant to handle, and the sliding front panel promises sturdy protection from the hazards of my jeans pocket (where I habitually keep my compact cameras).So how are the pictures? Mostly the same as those taken by my other subcompacts. I gave the camera a workout in bright sun, shade, fluorescent light, incandescent light, and very low light. The scene settings work quite well and the Auto setting does a good job of selecting exposure and ISO. You could just set it on "Auto," leave it there, and never worry about it again if you're not a fan of fiddling with cameras.There were a few ways in which I thought this camera was inferior to my Canon subcompacts, though. First -- the Auto White Balance setting wasn't quite as accurate as on my Canons. Second -- the lens lets in less light, causing more grain in very dark scenes. The Canons excel at capturing very low-light shots with minimal blur and grain. Finally, the lens is not as much to my liking. All subcompact cameras have a wide-angle lens that tends to create a fisheye effect, but it was slightly more marked in this camera than in my Canons. That means more distortion, but it also means it's easier to photograph groups or any wide scene.But there's a lot to like, too. The 14MP image size, though it may seem a waste of memory, is actually a real blessing in situations where you need to crop a shot for printing, or make enlargements. You can shoot great-looking widescreen HD video. And unlike my Canons, which have a delicate cover for their lens and a thin finish that dings really easily, this camera has a tough exoskeleton to keep it safe.One note -- the reviewer who said you can put the battery in backwards was right. The trick to getting it in the right orientation is to align the orange stripe on the battery with the orange tab that holds in the battery.The Fuji Finepix Z85 is a great choice if you need a reasonably-priced, tough, attractive and versatile camera for vacation snapshots, party photos, Facebook postings, and the like. It's an excellent compromise between image quality, features, size, and portability. And it's really important to have at least one camera that's sturdy, small, and easy to take along. Because, as they say, "The camera you have with you always takes better pictures than the camera at home in the closet."

Reviews.Title: Great outdoors, sucks indoors!!
Reviews.Author: Sandra in Tx
Reviews.Content: I just purchased this camera about 2 weeks ago. The last camera I had was a Kodak and I had that one for over 2 years until this past March I dropped it and the exterior zoom lens got stuck and no longer works which is why I had to buy a new one.There are several specs that got my attention with this camera such as: interior zoom lens (broke 2 camera from zoom lens), touch screen, slim size and it starts up pretty fast, 3 inch screen.Reasons I will be returning this camera: I just came home from watching my son's 5th grade class perform and was excited to upload them so that I could email to family and friends. As I was going through the pictures I was just saddened to see how poorly the pictures came out. Now let me say that I have had cameras for many years so I know my way around a camera and settings. That being said I made sure it was set up for indoor use and optional flash and what not. I compared this brand new camera pictures to my 2 year old Kodak camera pictures and the difference is soo big that I have NO other choice than to return and start all over again. As mentioned above, I was eager thinking I found just what I needed for a good price that will take good pictures. I was proven wrong.After returning this camera tonight, I will be looking into Kodak, Sony or Samsung... I should have listened to my husband!!Works decent outdoors but a $50 camera does too. The indoor pics were just NO GOOD!! Might be good for someone who is starting out with a camera but for someone  like myself who enjoys taking pictures of family events and whatnot, it just didn't stand up to the test.Hope this review helps others....

Reviews.Title: some cool features, but many problems
Reviews.Author: Silea
Reviews.Content: First, the good:I love that the lens cover slidey-thing is also the power switch. There's no itty bitty little round button to push. You never have to worry that you've left the camera on after you cover the lens and toss it in your bag. Sure, you can't look at the pictures you've already taken while also keeping the lens covered, but that's hardly a major issue.I also love that the touch-screen allowed them to get rid of almost all the buttons. There's the button to take a picture, the button to start or stop video recording, and a button to switch from picture mode to review mode, and another button to switch back. That's it. Four buttons. Five, if you count the zoom dial as a button. Compare that to any camera with similar features.And, well, most of the time it takes pretty good pictures. You get about 600 at the highest quality settings on a 4-gig card (or twelve whole minutes of HD video), so you don't need to shell out the big bucks for a giant SD card just to make it so you'll always run out of battery before you run out of memory.Then, the middling:This camera uses a different USB cord than every other camera i have, or have had in the past. I liked that i, until now, only needed one cable on my desk, regardless of whether i was transferring pictures from my dSLR, my old canon point-and-shoot, or my camcorder. Now, alas, i have two.The battery looks cheap. It works fine, but again, unlike every other camera i have or have had, Fuji didn't bother putting the battery in a solid plastic case, so it's this odd, shiny white plastic thing instead. Maybe it shaved a dollar off the price, but i'd never be comfortable tossing this battery in a bag without putting it in some sort of hard container (though i do admit, i rarely carry my batteries outside of their camera).And, alas, the bad:The picture quality is not consistent. Pictures are very washed-out on overcast days, which makes this camera useless outdoors about ten months out of the year up here in the Pacific Northwest. Even with the flash, indoor pictures are pretty shoddy unless the environment is ridiculously well-lit. So for sunny days in the park, you'll get crystal-clear images with brilliant color. The rest of the time, well, good luck.The touch-screen isn't very responsive, especially the menu button in the lower left corner.The set-up options are arranged oddly. To turn off all the chintzy sound effects, you have to go to each one individually, there's no global 'sound off' option. Since you only get a quick-start guide in the box, unless you print out the full user manual from the internet, you'll be doing a lot of clicking through every single set-up option to find what you want.Images shown on the touch-screen are low quality, and often orange-shifted. When i first used this camera, i thought all of the pictures (even the sunny outdoors ones) were going to be terrible, because every time i reviewed them on the camera, they looked like smudgy orange-tinted old cell phone pictures. Once i uploaded them onto my computer, many of them were just fine.The camera is very slow to adjust the focus if you change the zoom in HD video mode. Sometimes it doesn't adjust at all. So if you use this camera for videos, keep your finger clear of the zoom dial, or you'll end up with a lot of High-Def fuzzy blurs.If you just want a camera to take quick pictures in well-lighted situations, this camera will do just fine. For people who are intimidated by all the buttons and such on modern cameras, this camera will be great. The slide-cover on the front will be much easier for older people to handle than the tiny itty bitty little power buttons on most little cameras. But for anyone with a moderate grip on the state of modern technology and fingers nimble enough to handle a few small buttons, stay clear of this camera.--Update!More bad: after endless frustration trying to hit the buttons on the touch screen (i have pretty small fingers, and never have trouble on other touch-screen devices), i found the 'calibrate' option buried in the menu. It takes you to the calibrate mode, where little X shapes appear on the screen, and you try to touch them. On most devices, this means the device will 'learn' if you have a systematic bias - if when you think you're hitting the X, you're always a little off to the right, the device will 'learn' that and adjust accordingly. This camera? Hah. If you miss the X, it tells you to try again. The Calibrate option isn't for calibrating the camera, it's for calibrating the user. Honestly, this is so stupid that i wouldn't believe it if I hadn't experienced it myself.

Reviews.Title: Good Pocket Camera But 1 Major Flaw
Reviews.Author: MsAlexisGames "Gamer 4 life"
Reviews.Content: Alright guys, so I got this camera (in red) for Christmas 2011. I've taken a few pictures with it and am loving the image quality. Not the best quality but for a cheap point and shoot pocket camera it's better than I expected it to be. I've recorded 2 videos with it, 1 in SD to test the standard quality as well as in HD (just earlier today) to test the quality of high def. Now I must say for a cheap camera the video quality is awesome. There is one major drawback that I must address about this camera that I'll get to later. I'm loving the touch screen of this camera though its responsiveness isn't always there. The options for taking pictures is good if you want to take advantage of the touch screen ( I haven't done so yet and probably won't but it's nice to have) and take pictures using the screen. One drawback is that it is high gloss on the body, so if you plan to use this camera often expect it to be a fingerprint magnet.Now to get to the major flaw.I put in a Class 4 4 GB SD card from my previous camera. It only records 12 minutes of HD video and 30 minutes of standard video. Now I thought being a class 4 that that was the issue on the recording being so minimal on top of it being a 14 megapixel camera. I tried adjusting the settings and it does nothing for the recording limit, so I figured then it was because it was a class 4. I then ordered 2 days ago on Amazon a 16GB Class 10 (yes major upgrade in class) SD card with Free 2 day shipping with prime. I thought it's 4 times the size and it's 2 and a half times the speed so this must do the trick. *buzzer* Boy was I wrong. I put in the SD card today to find out it had the same recording limit as before (12 minutes HD and 30 minutes SD). I'm now pissed off and don't know what else to do except write a review giving my honest thoughts in hopes that someone can help me out. My honest opinion all in all is that it's a good camera but sucks in that it doesn't record a lot of video.If anyone else has had this came issue for video recording let me know. Also let me know if you found a way around this problem.Fugifilm you guys have both a happy and pissed off customer with this camera.[edit]Okay so I read the manual. Come to find out you can't record video longer than 2 gigs per recording. Which is a major major flaw. If you're going to have a video recorder on the camera, why not let it record one recording based on the size of the memory card? Like I said before, Fugifilm has both a happy and pissed off customer with this camera. But knowing this information lets me know that this camera is to be used for images instead of video and images. I'm glad I found out this information. I thank my uncle for looking into it instead of buying another memory card.

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm FinePix Z90
Reviews.Author: loopy
Reviews.Content: So far I'm thrilled w/ this camera.  I wanted a touch screen- rechargeable battery- digital camera for not a lot of benjermins.  2 of my famlily  memebers have older Fuji digital cameras & love them. So after  I dropped my Polaroid digital - I chose the Fuji camera. So far whats bothered me w/this camera are: 1)- you have to take the battery out & charge it I was expecting  just a cord to recharge it ( like my other family members have)  2) the location of the lens-  my finger - until you get used to it- was always in a pic.  3)you do need to read the user's manuel 1st. there is so much  put into this  camera.It fits perfectly in a pocket and  purse..  I do recommend this camera for 1st timers. It is easy to handle & doesn't take a rocket sceintist to understand it. The picture quality to me is good although I admit I haven't developed any of my pics yet but does any one do that any more? I just downloaded them and sent them out. I took some out side & in doors and was satisfied.

Reviews.Title: "Interesting" Change
Reviews.Author: MussSyke
Reviews.Content: This camera is what I call a "subcompact" - the smallest point and shoot cameras that have vertically mounted lenses which allow protection, compactness, and quicker start up times.  Normally, you'd expect a small trade off for these features, so I wouldn't compare this directly with a camera endowed by a telescoping lens.Sony invented the subcompact with the T1 a few years back (at least in my world), and I was able to compare the FinePix Z90 with the one-generation-older 12 MP Sony T90.  I'll go the pro/con route...PROS of the Z90:-Price is something like half of the latest subcompact Sony.-Operational costs are cheaper:  USB cable is non-proprietary (in case you want a second one or need to replace it) and SD card is cheaper and more universal than Sony's Memory Stick.-Separate physical buttons to record movies and to take pictures.  This is genius to me, because I hate to miss a great video opportunity while fumbling through the menus.-Does not come with a memory card, BUT cameras that do usually come with one so small that it is worthless.  Internal memory is better, because it allows you to copy from one camera card to another, which can be useful.-Can set it up to take two photos at once, with and without the flash.  As an amateur, I often do this manually anyway, but this way you get closer photos (chronologically)to compare in a dynamic scenario, and the subject needs only to pose once.-The panorama mode works better than in other cameras I've used.  They use internal weights alla smart phones (I'm guessing) to help you line up the next picture.  Allows you to "pan" a panorama shot in play mode.-There is a time zone mode that allows you to temporarily change the time (for timestamps).-The display changes from horizontal to vertical as you move the camera respectively.-"Touch and track" mode follows a subject.-Side by side picture compare.-Search by face, couple, group, favorites, scene, or date, and view a small picture next to thumbnails.-Charger is smaller with the plug offset to allow it to use only one receptacle on a power strip (as long as it is at the end of said strip).CONS of the Z90:-Picture quality was not as good as the Sony 80% of the time (tested in various modes and lighting conditions).  That said, a tripod really helps with low light and no flash, where both cameras struggle without it.-By numbers, it is not much larger than the Sony, but it feels significantly larger.-Sometimes the "buttons" in the corners of the touch screen need to be pressed more than once.-Tripod mount has plastic threads, instead of a machined metal insert.-Cannot take shots as rapidly as on the Sony-Does not tell you what zoom level you are at.  5x zoom does not appear to make a great difference over 4x.-"play" and "camera" buttons could be one button used as a toggle.-Battery can be put in backward, as the slot is not keyed (although the battery is).  No big deal, but shows something wasn't thought out thoroughly.Bottom Line:The Fuji is trying to deliver everything the market leader has to offer for a much more manageable price tag.  It gets an A for effort, delivering a lot of great menu options, and may actually win in that respect, but the picture quality is not as good.  If they could pour a little more money into the actual optics and the touch screen and still keep the price reasonable, they might win the battle in the future.  For now, it's purely a personal budget vs. quality decision.

Reviews.Title: It's Just Okay
Reviews.Author: McBean "BJMcBean"
Reviews.Content: Generally I use a large format digital SLR but it doesn't exactly fit in my purse. This camera works fine for spur-of-the-moment shots, but I find that the menus are difficult to use. Because all the selections are activated with a touch screen, it's difficult to make quick changes because one has to wade through various menu options. Plus, I have a tendency to accidentally press the video button which is dangerously close to the shutter.I do like the sliding lens cover that also turns on the camera; however, the cover has inadvertently slid open more than once and worn down the battery.The camera definitely feels sturdy enough. Removing and replacing the battery and SD card is simple.

Reviews.Title: Nice Size, Good Pictures
Reviews.Author: Richard Wagoner
Reviews.Content: I've owned and tried out quite a few digital cameras over the years, from various brands. This Fujifilm camera comes in about in the middle for me. Not that this is a bad thing, as the cameras I would rate higher cost a bit more.What I like about this one is the size: very thin compared to many, but with a decent size and balance that makes it easy to hold and use. I have a love-hate relationship with the lends cover that doubles as a power switch, as it opens easy enough to open while in my backpack, draining the battery as it "travelled." On the other hand, it IS handy and it does a very nice job protecting the lens.Picture quality seems typical for this price range. Fabulous outdoors, decent indoors. The flash is not amazingly powerful but again, typical for the price range.The touch screen works reasonably well and the camera is intuitive enough that if you know anything about digital cameras, you probably do not need to read the manual. I let my son try it out and he had no problem at all using it for both stills and videos.Videos are not that great (say a 3 out of 5) but overall I'd say this is a solid 4 out of 5.

Reviews.Title: Pretty good camera.
Reviews.Author: heathermartin1
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera about a month ago and it was priced at $140. Now, it's only $110. I should've waited. Anyways, the camera takes fairly good pictures. However, indoor pictures are sometimes blurry. I'm only 17 and this is my first camera, so I think it's pretty good.

Reviews.Title: Camera is great but battery is weak.
Reviews.Author: Yuh-Fang Lee
Reviews.Content: Great camera. Easy to figure out the new features.Only 2 things that I didn't expect when ordering it.1) Battery is weak. Or the battery level displayed on the screen is incorrect. It could start with a full measure and then suddenly lower to a red alarm. I don't know what's wrong with it.2) My laptop has a built-in SD card reader, and I used to be able to read the same card from my old camera. But now I am not able to read it. I think the file format on my new FUJI must be different, or something else.

Reviews.Title: Terrible Experience
Reviews.Author: Hermonie
Reviews.Content: This camera's easy slide front turns itself on with the slightest bump and your battery is constantly dead because it was taking pictures of the inside of its case.  To top it off it broke in less than 6 months.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful camera and an A1 product!!
Reviews.Author: Sandra L. Stuart
Reviews.Content: This camera is a beautiful color and works perfectly! Its a lot of fun and is one that I recommend because the lens is protected from dirt and sand!

Reviews.Title: Battery Life = -
Reviews.Author: Stackmann
Reviews.Content: I wanted to replace my Z5 and liked the looks and specs of this camera.  My only issue is battery life.  I leave my camera on my desk until I need it.  With tith camera I must have a second battery fully charged.  The battery in the camera on my desktop will only last 3 days.  My older camera would last months.  Bad Engineering.

Reviews.Title: Smaller Isn't Always Better
Reviews.Author: Dianne E. Socci-Tetro "Never Judge a Book by ...
Reviews.Content: As I get older, things are certainly getting smaller.  Sometimes that is a very good thing.  HOWEVER, sometimes it just isn't.  In my opinion while I like the smaller camera's that we have now-  sometimes they just try to stuff too much into a tiny little package.  In addition, when that happens people (some people of course) of a certain age may find that buttons are too small to see or positioned where someone with larger fingers can't get to easily.  The touch screen is lovely unless you have longish nails or stiffness in your fingers and then this can be feature can be somewhat annoying.  3 times out of ten I ended up with my finger in front of the picture and that just started to drive me crazy. These are just some of the problems that I am having with this very compact multi-use camera.  This camera certainly does it all; it takes close ups, action shots, movies...you name the action and Fujifilmn stuffed it into this tiny package.  It fits wonderfully into my smaller purses and takes perfectly adequate pictures, but I must admit...unless you are a camera or gadget lover, I just can't see  the point of spending so much money on a camera that does essentially what most people's phones  do nowadays.

Reviews.Title: Not a good choice unless you are VERY still or use a tripod
Reviews.Author: William Hardin
Reviews.Content: So first off the pros:It is small, skinny and a fun color.It has TONS of features and options and those features are generally well thought out and easy enough to use.It has an internal lens so you prevent the number was cause of digital camera failure.Cons:The internal lens (think tiny light capturing) combined with cheaper components means you need more light to take decent photos and to be still as a rock (as the Fujifilm tries to slow picture taking down to capture more light.) These faults mean 75% of your average photos are going to be disappointing. You are going to find blurry, dark, pixelated, and in some cases when you do have plenty of light, washed out looking photos.It is enough of a problem I would not recommend this camera to anyone. (Having sold managed a digital camera department for Best Buy as well as having used more than 100 digital cameras I rarely make such strong statements. I am not just a random person playing around or someone who didn't try to manually fix the shortcomings in the automatic settings.)If you want a small camera, I would look at Sony and Canon for much better options.

Reviews.Title: A WHOLE LOT IN A LITTLE PACKAGE
Reviews.Author: Orrin C. Judd "brothersjudddotcom"
Reviews.Content: Our 9-year old son and I test drove the camera at a soccer friendly in Foxboro and he not only had no trouble using it to produce quality photos but the movies he shot with it are better than any video camera we ever owned.  Can't recommend it highly enough as a family-friendly camera.

Reviews.Title: Good little pocket camera
Reviews.Author: offwatch
Reviews.Content: We have been beating up cameras that have the lens pop out when you turn it on. We bought this one because the lens does not have to popout to take a picture. The cover that is manually pulled over the lens to shut off the camera is fairly robust. The camera has most of the basic features. The large touch screen viewer is better than most. It takes OK pictures. Some of our pictures are taken on a tripod - so the 2 second timer on the shutter release is a good feature to minimize camera shake. The macro mode does not seem to allow you to get much closer to the object. I wish I could control either the F-stop or shutter speed in a semi-auto mode.It fits good in almost any pocket and is well protected until you point and shoot. Don't expect DSLR results, but you can get good snap shots in places you might not take a DSLR.The owners manual leaves a lot to be desired when you want to do some more advanced work. It uses a lot space making excuses for why a picture may not have come out. I guess that most people only break out the manual when something does not turn out like expected.

Reviews.Title: Great design, Great features, Great camera!
Reviews.Author: CJ-MO
Reviews.Content: The Fujifilm FinePix Z90 is a great point and shoot camera. It comes in a variety of colors, but I like the bright red finish of the camera I have. The design is unique from other cameras - it resembles a wallet or envelope. To turn the camera on, you simply slide the lens cover down; this is the part of the camera that looks like an envelope flap. Some of the options are a little harder to use than other small cameras, but the available features are worth a little time to learn to use.Besides the stylish design, I like the many innovative features of the camera. For example, it's very easy to switch from playback to camera mode with the buttons on the camera. Once in playback mode, I found the functionality to have many more options compared to other similar cameras. You can compare photos side-by-side or with the press of an on-screen button, you can display thumbnails of several photos at once.There are too many features to describe each one in detail, but below is a summary of my favorites:* Good picture quality for size and type of camera* Many settings manageable by touching the screen* Robust playback mode* Includes lithium ion battery and charger* Ability to take one photo without flash and immediately take same picture with flash and compare results side-by-side (Great for taking an initial photo to test lighting conditions)* Can load photos to PC even without the included software using standard windows functionality* In Playback mode, can go to Menu and select specific photo. Then when photos are loaded to the PC, only those selected photos will be uploaded to Facebook.* Zoom in/out easily by touching a round button on top of the camera - easier to get to and use than the bars on other cameras that must be tapped on one end or the other to zoom in and out* Can select a mode that allows a photo to be taken by touching the screen instead of the shutter button* When turning the camera vertically to take a picture, the menu options are automatically displayed in a portrait mode so they are easy to readOverall, this camera has several unique, up-to-date features that are surprising, especially for a camera at this price point. The stylish design makes it a great choice for adults or teens. Facebook and YouTube users will appreciate the technology making is easier than ever to post photos and video clips. If you're looking for a small camera with a fun design and new features, the FinePix is worth a second look.

Reviews.Title: A top-of-the-line amateur camera
Reviews.Author: Moviedude
Reviews.Content: When my wife's old J10 got busted, we decided to stick with Fujifilm. This camera is basically the logical upgrade from that unit, and it's slightly more feature-rich than similarly-priced cameras aimed at "serious" photographers.The Z90 has a lot of nifty settings and takes good looking pics. It has a powerful flash which will unfortunately drain the battery rapidly. The touchscreen is intuitive but a bit finickey (use your fingernail!) and is a big step up from the context-sensitive buttons or command wheels on older models. All the picture modes seem useful, and I found them all pretty easy to work out. You can even tap stuff to shoot it if you're used to smartphones. Zoom is clear and usable. Macro mode, like on our J10, works really well. The camera itself looks great and boasts a slide-open activation that's fairly intuitive. Low light focusing takes a few seconds, but the images come out pretty clear. Like the J10 the body feels solid and well-built.Criticisms are few but would include the finicky detection on some buttons on the touch screen and the fact that 38MB of on-board memory is a total joke for the huge pictures this camera can take. Of course you'll be using memory cards so this is no deal-breaker.Note that you will want a carrying case as the touchscreen occupies most of the back of the camera and there are no points for mounting a protective cover.

Reviews.Title: Fuji
Reviews.Author: Neil Chapman
Reviews.Content: Unrateable. Poor resolution, the camera battery runs flat very quickly and some how the camera keeping coming on in ones pocket.

Reviews.Title: Mine Was Used!!
Reviews.Author: adkjess
Reviews.Content: My camera came in a dirty box with a broken seal. It had pictures from a store already on it, along with a short video of shoppers. I can't believe they sent me a used camera when I paid for a new one. Very dissatisfied & am just glad it shipped free in 2 days. Indoor pictures are terrible & outdoors are pretty nice. If it had of been new my review would be completely different but it is what it is & I wish I had of picked something else. Oh & mine shipped from Big Value.

Reviews.Title: Excellent compact camera!
Reviews.Author: Eric A. Ryan
Reviews.Content: This is an extremely nice compact point and shoot camera.  Metal body, high quality pictures for a basic camera, and no telescoping lense (it uses some unique system for the optical zoom, but it is an optical zoom and not simply a digital zoom).The manual needs to be downloaded online (the one that comes with the camera is minimal).  However, you don't need it to start taking basic pictures.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: CLR from PA
Reviews.Content: This is a lot of camera for the money. I love the color blue and the very small size. So glad  I purchase it.

Reviews.Title: Good camera and delivered on time!
Reviews.Author: Margaret Kim Rasbury "happy mom"
Reviews.Content: My 22 year  old daughter got this for Christmas and loves it.  Even though it says iit needs an SDXC card, an SD HC cards works fine (and is much less expensive).So fr, it's a good solid camera for her.

Reviews.Title: Pretty good for a point and shoot
Reviews.Author: Arielle Gordon
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for a trip to Europe and it worked really really well. the video quality is pretty good and it automatically adjusts for the lighting in the area to take the best picture. i had the flash off most of the time, and if you try to take a really fast photo that way you can get some blurry photos, but in general they were pretty decent. if you're looking to take really fast pictures, you're probably better off with an iphone or an android camera because the quality is more consistantly good. if you're looking to take slightly fancier photos, artistic shots ect, this camera is pretty good for that. plus, because the lens doesn't have to come out, it turns on in only like 3 seconds and is ready to go and then ready to be stored pretty fast

Reviews.Title: Why so Blurry!
Reviews.Author: Masface
Reviews.Content: I got this camera because it was a great price for a brand camera. It had all the cool features and 14mp, so I was excited. The problem Im having is the images are blurry, no matter what I do, they are always blurry! I set the camera on a stable surface..blurry...it's so frustrating! I turned on the image stabilization and I can get 1-2 decent pictures. This camera ruined our family Christmas Light trip...halfway through, I got tired and started to use my iPhone 4S camera...way better pictures than this took. Sending it back tomorrow.

Reviews.Title: Solid Point-And-Shoot
Reviews.Author: Doc Holladay "No sentence should ever begin w...
Reviews.Content: My wife and I purchased this for my mom for Christmas, because the digital camera she was using was ten years old and the size of a brick.I played around with this camera, so it would be set up and ready for her to use (she's not tech saavy in any way). The controls are fairly straight forward, although a little more in depth for someone who is looking for a simple to use camera. I'm up in the air about the touch screen feature, however it beats numerous buttons on the back, and allows for a larger screen (3 inch). The housing doesn't feel cheap, but the camera itself is light-weight and compact).Al in all, I feel this will be a good camera for my mom, and that she will be able to get a lot of use out of it.UPDATE:So it's been a year since we bought this for my mom. We went over to their house for Christmas Eve this year, and she was still using it (the whole time we were there, I might add). I asked her how she liked it, and she said she loves it. As I figured (and mentioned in the original review), she said it is a little more feature-rich than she needs, but for someone looking for a decent little point-and-shoot, this seems to do the trick without any headaches.

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm FinePix Z90 14 MP
Reviews.Author: Xavier Cisneros
Reviews.Content: I like the product, is a camera for use by many 12 year old daughter and her use the camera gives very efficient. the pictures are clear and the touch screen is very easy to control applications

Reviews.Title: Excellent choice for touch-screen camera
Reviews.Author: Joe Shen
Reviews.Content: I have this just for the touch-screen function. I have checked the Sony and the price was a lot higher so this one is good for me and the my daughter love the touch-screen features.

Reviews.Title: Z90 Forfilling
Reviews.Author: Dorman Brandon Jr. "up to date"
Reviews.Content: I had a Z10, but lost it on a trip, for me to stay with Fuji-film says it all. The Z90 is all I am looking for in a camera, it's easy, and uncomplicated, very good product.

Reviews.Title: 5 Star
Reviews.Author: Deb
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera I bought it for a gift and my friend thinks it is just great I will probably buy another for myself. A good camera all around especially for beginners in the digital world. Small, takes up very little space in your bag.

Reviews.Title: Best Camera I've Had in Years
Reviews.Author: Olivia Stabler
Reviews.Content: This camera is amazing - it has so many great features. One feature I really like is that the wall charger for the camera is very compact, doesn't have any wires, and doesn't require you to charge the entire camera on a tabletop like most models. For this camera, you just take the battery out of the camera and snap it into the charger. Also, when it's completely charged, it has a green light to indicate it's finished. The camera itself is compact and fits easily inside any case - I love how it has a slide down lens cover, which also turns it on when you slide it down.The photos come out crisp and in high definition and the zoom range is excellent and clear. The only problem with that is when you zoom in as far as it will go, the photos come out a little grainy. By far the best feature is the large touch screen on which you can view stored photos, adjust all the settings, and record video. It's extremely user friendly. The only thing I didn't really like was that when you record videos, the sound is poor on playback and there wasn't a setting to adjust that. But overall, this camera is well worth the money.

Reviews.Title: A Goldmine For Candid Street Photography
Reviews.Author: B. Brewer
Reviews.Content: I would consider myself an advanced amateur in photography.  I own MANY cameras and this camera also has a place in my life, it's perfect for candid, street, out-and-about photography.  Inconspicuous in design, small and compact, it is nearly undetectable to others which make a superb camera in this department.  I love the flip close panel that protects the lens and it's ready to use in the flick of a wrist--no camera case needed, I can just slip it in my pocket.  I took this to a department store and snapped some photos of random people and NOBODY noticed I was taking a photo of them! LOVE the design and it's small size.The only downfall that I can detect at the moment is it's performance in low light conditions.  Inside shots with lower shutter speeds come out blurry and shaky.

Reviews.Title: Love this point and shoot!
Reviews.Author: Sam I Am
Reviews.Content: Cool interface, convenient size makes this camera the perfect point and shoot to take with you everywhere.The optical resolution, color saturation and contrast are perfectly acceptable for the quick photo on the fly.  I keep this camera in my briefcase and use it to document property in the field for my business.Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm FinePix Z90 Video Review
Reviews.Author: S. E. Rhoads "WordTipping"
